poem:
"Echoes of a Labour's Love"

In the melancholy silence of the morning, 
I sipped a tale of blood and belonging, 
Of a lineage in Labour, a history unfolding. 
Railwaymen and councillors, a tale of the olden. 
Yet, amidst the echoes of ancestry, a parting pain,
A membership cancelled, a sense of self in strain,
Stockport's son, now a dissenter in the rain.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Labour party is in my blood. Here’s why I’ve just cancelled my membership | Owen Jones It’s difficult to disentangle Labour from my sense of self. Grew up in Stockport, looks a bit like Macaulay Culkin, bad dress sense … the Labour party always seemed to fit in there somewhere. My great-grandfather, a railwayman who had his wages docked in the General Strike nearly a century ago, was a Labour councillor. So was my". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
